Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Electrostatic Mechanisms in Protein Stability and Folding

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this CAREER project is to develop and apply new theoretical methods and molecular simulation techniques to characterize the denatured states and to discern residue-specific electrostatic contributions to the stability of model proteins including NTL9, HP36 and leucine zippers. This research will tackle two outstanding problems that hamper theoretical studies of denatured and disordered proteins, namely, the lack of rigorous means to validate microscopic information and the problem of force field bias. Electrostatic interactions play an important role in biological functions. However, the current knowledge of electrostatic effects is incomplete. This is because experimental techniques cannot isolate electrostatic contributions, while the accuracy of existing theoretical studies is insufficient. The developed simulation tools and software will be disseminated to the community to advance atomic-level studies of electrostatic phenomena and many important biological processes involving denatured states and disordered proteins.

To help prepare a new generation of work force with state-of-the-art scientific knowledge as well as critical thinking and problem solving skills, the PI will develop new curricula that integrate classroom teaching and hands-on research projects. The broader educational impacts also include a web site (http://computchem.org) dedicated to students who are interested in learning and applying theoretical and computational tools to problems in the cross-disciplinary areas of biology, chemistry, and physics. Modern communication tools such as Blogs, Forums, Wikis, and Media are offered to promote peer learning and knowledge sharing in a world-wide community. The PI will give seminars and host summer interns to further enhance learning experience and to increase participation of underrepresented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Shen and a team of graduate students and postdocs further developed a molecular simulation tool called continuous constant pH molecular dynamics (CpHMD) and applied the tool to advance the fundamental understanding of pH-dependent mechanisms of a variety of systems involving enzymes, transmembrane proteins, surfactants and polysaccharides. Specifically, Shen and coworkers developed the hybrid-solvent and all-atom GRF- and PME-based CpHMD methods, which offer significantly improved accuracy in predicting protonation states compared to the previous generalized-Born implicit-solvent based CpHMD method. Importantly, these methods enabled pKa predictions for transmembrane proteins, surfactants and polysaccharides, which were not previously possible. Employing the new methods, Shen and coworkers performed the first constant pH simulations to investigate 1) the relationship between the pH-dependent flap dynamics and the enzymatic activity of BACE1, a major target of Alzheimer’s disease; 2) the cooperativity of a controversial downhill folding miniprotein BBL; 3) the mechanism of pH-triggered self assembly of peptide amphophiles and amino-polysaccharides; 4) details of conformational activation of the M2 proton channel from influenza virus; 5) the mechanism of ion-proton exchange in sodium-proton antiporter NhaA; 6) the stoichiometry and conformational transition of the multi-drug efflux pump AcrB.

Intellectual Merits. Our work is transformative in two ways. First, the developed tools enable the control of solution pH in explicit-solvent molecular simulations, which further increases the physical realism and transforms computational studies of pH-dependent dynamic processes that are currently not well understood. Second, the application studies refined our understanding of protein dynamics-function relationships and protein-ligand binding. They illuminated the precise role of protons in facilitating ion and substrate transport across biological membranes. Thus, our studies pushed the boundary of current molecular simulations in several topic areas and set the stage for advancing fundamental knowledge of proton-mediated processes that play important roles in biology, human health and material design.

Broader Impacts. The impact of our research has extended far beyond computational biophysics. For example, our work demonstrated that constant pH molecular simulations can be applied to refine the design and optimization of small-molecule inhibitors targeting diseases, amphoteric surfactants for consumer products, and chitosan-based hydrogels for bioelectronics. To communicate science to general public and help prepare the next generation STEM workforce, Dr. Shen held seminars at minority colleges, led a science-inspired art project and organized a regional symposium for graduate students, and hosted internships for high school students.
